bill.title: Gun Violence Research Act
bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 163, Number 41 (Thursday, March 9, 2017)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mrs. MURPHY of Florida:H.R. 1478.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Congress has the power to enact the Gun Violence ResearchAct of 2017 pursuant to Article I, Section 8, Clause 18, theNecessary and Proper Clause. The Necessary and Proper Clausesupports the expansion of congressional authority beyond theexplicit authorities that are directly discernible from thetext. Additionally, the Preamble to the Constitution providessupport of the authority to enact legislation to promote theGeneral Welfare.[Page H2020]

item.latestTitle: Expressing support for the designation of June 2017 as "National Gun Violence Awareness Month" and calling on Congress to address gun violence.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Crime, Terrorism, Homeland Security, and Investigations.

item.title: To repeal the provision that in practice prohibits the Department of Health and Human Services from sponsoring research on gun violence in fiscal year 2017, and for other purposes.

item.titleType: (Extracted from GPO) Short Titles as Introduced
item.title: Gun Violence Research Act

item.name: Introduced in House
item.text:
Gun Violence Research Act

This bill amends the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2016 to eliminate the prohibition on the Department of Health and Human Services using federal funds to advocate or promote gun control.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
